{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3608323,"name":"","username":"Showblown","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/b4bc9f/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-04-30T19:06:46.364Z","cooked":"

Hi, I was looking at PathPlanner’s Pathfinding, and was interested in their Pathfind then follow path. (Pathfinding | PathPlanner Docs). Is it possible to follow an auto after Pathfinding to it in order to do autonomous scoring or is this exclusive to paths?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2025-04-30T19:06:46.364Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":248,"readers_count":247,"score":69.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":500965,"topic_slug":"question-about-pathplanners-pathfinding","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://pathplanner.dev/pplib-pathfinding.html#pathfind-then-follow-path","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Pathfinding | PathPlanner Docs","clicks":7}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65011,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programming Lead - 3189 Circuit Breakers"},"post_url":"/t/question-about-pathplanners-pathfinding/500965/1","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3608366,"name":"Eric (319)","username":"EKM_319","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ekm_319/{size}/230932_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-30T20:00:06.545Z","cooked":"

While I haven’t done it myself. ( to be honest i haven’t had much luck with named commands/events in pathplanner. And prefer making command groups of paths and actions… which is probably gross )

I think you could make a sequential command group to pathfind and then perform an auto.

Pretty sure it’s just the following if you wanted to get the command for an ‘auto’ instead of a specific path.

‘’’ new PathPlannerAuto(“Example Auto”); ‘’’

I’m assuming that events are baked into autos and not paths. But i could be wrong. For all I know you may be able to just say pathfind then follow path and if events are on said path perhaps they run.

Again. This may be kludge.

You can use the pathfind to coordinate feature and use the auton start location (I think you can go to the first path’s location in the auton:.path/.auto files). then you can just pathfind to that.

How would you run the auto after pathfinding there? Would you just use the example in the docs and replace the path name with an auto? Or would you need to run a sequential command group like the person above said?

This is an instance where the command-based structure really shines, since everything in PathPlannerLib is built around commands.

While PathPlanner does provide AutoBuilder.pathfindThenFollowPath(), it also gives us AutoBuilder.pathfindToPose()—and both of these return commands. That means you can easily sequence one of them with a PathPlannerAuto, which is also just a command!

One thing to watch out for: if your auto starts with an initial velocity, make sure to pass that into the pathfinding method so it can generate a valid path.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2025-05-03T05:43:19.251Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":102,"readers_count":101,"score":45.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":500965,"topic_slug":"question-about-pathplanners-pathfinding","display_username":"Carlos Salazar","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://pathplanner.dev/pplib-pathfinding.html#pathfind-to-pose","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Pathfinding | PathPlanner Docs","clicks":4},{"url":"https://pathplanner.dev/pplib-build-an-auto.html#load-an-auto","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Build an Auto | PathPlanner Docs","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57451,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programming & Electrical Captain"},"post_url":"/t/question-about-pathplanners-pathfinding/500965/5","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3610848,"name":"Nolan Barker","username":"therekrab","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/therekrab/{size}/248500_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-03T21:00:39.053Z","cooked":"

In my opinion, the easiest thing to do here is to add a NamedCommand in your auton sequence in pathplanner. If that command is your drive-to-point command (however you want to implement it), then if you simply run the rest of the sequence, you’ll get the results you’re looking for.

Just make sure to disable the “reset odometry” setting if you do this.

One side note though: if you’re trying to drive to a point, then run an auton, you probably are trying to drive to the “correct” auton start point for your auton.
Instead of implementing some solution yourself, if your robot is (reasonably) close to the ideal starting point, pathplanner can correct for you. By disabling the “reset odometry” option, you can tell the robot to adjust to inconsistencies in the path’s start state.

The main advantage of this is that it doesn’t change the time the robot takes to follow the path. The adjustments drive the robot to where it should be in the path, rather than drive to a dedicated location then start the path. However, its best feature is also its biggest liability. If the robot is significantly off, the time the path takes will exceed the time that pathplanner thinks it should. This leads to the path ending early at a position that is not where it “should” finish. Again, this isn’t really an issue if your robot begins at about the right spot, but it is good to keep in mind.

So you’re saying the just put the auton afterwards in something like a sequential command group?
